DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to represent the results of a graphic tracing (electrocardiogram) that documents an abnormal rate of muscle contractions in the heart.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Summary finding (abnormal or normal) based on an electrocardiogram.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that displays the electrical activity of the heart.

Property.preferredDefinition: Clinical manifestations that can be either objective when observed by a physician, or subjective when perceived by the patient.

Concepts.definition: Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text terms that describe the results of electrocardiography tracing documenting an abnormal rhythm of the heart.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tachycardia arising distal to bundle of His, with a rate greater than 100 beats per minute.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of three or more consecutive complexes of ventricular origin with a rate greater than a certain threshold (100 or 120 beats per minute are commonly used). The QRS complexes are wide and have an abnormal morphology. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding of a ventricular tachyarrhythmia characterized by smooth undulating waves with QRS complexes merged with T waves at a rate of approximately 250 per minute.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a high ventricular rate (180 to 250 beats per minute) with a regular rhythm and large oscillating sine wave-like complexes occurring as a result of QRS complexes and T waves being merged. The P wave is not visible.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a rapid grossly irregular ventricular rhythm with marked variability in QRS cycle length, morphology, and amplitude. The rate is typically greater than 300 bpm. (CDISC)

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a rapid grossly irregular ventricular rhythm with marked variability in QRS cycle length, morphology, and amplitude. The rate is typically greater than 300 bpm. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Irregular heart beat resulting from a pathologic process in the cardiac ventricles.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of an atypical cardiac rhythm resulting from a pathologic process in the cardiac ventricles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding of normal QRS followed by a premature ventricular contraction; a rhythmic pairing of normal and atypical beats originating from the ventricles in a 1:2 ratio.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of two sinus beats followed by a premature ventricular complex for 3 or more consecutive cycles; a regularly irregular rhythm of normal and abnormal QRS complexes in a 2-1 ratio. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An atypical rapid polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic rotation of the QRS complex around the isoelectric baseline. In addition the QRS complex displays a periodic waxing and waning of amplitude on the electrogram. (NCI)

Concepts.longName: Torsades De Pointes by ECG Finding
Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an atypical rapid polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic rotation of the QRS complex around the isoelectric baseline, occurring in the setting of a prolonged QT interval. In addition, the QRS complex displays a periodic waxing and waning of amplitude on the electrocardiogram.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding of a ventricular impulse originating before depolarization has completed.

Concepts.longName: Ventricular Premature Complex by ECG Finding
Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an ectopic impulse originating in the ventricles. The QRS morphology of these complexes is different from those of supraventricular origin. The QRS duration is often longer and the RR interval preceding the complexes is usually shorter than that of supraventricular beats. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding of a cardiac rhythm originating in the ventricles. The heart rate is usually regular and ranging between 30-40 beats per minute (the intrinsic ventricular rate), but can be higher or lower.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of three or more consecutive complexes of ventricular origin with a rate less than a certain threshold (100 or 120 beats per minute are commonly used). The QRS complexes are wide and have an abnormal morphology. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding of a normal QRS followed by a premature ventricular contraction; a rhythmic pairing of normal and abnormal beats originating in the ventricles in a 1-1 ratio. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of a normal QRS followed by a premature ventricular contraction; a rhythmic pairing of normal and atypical beats originating in the ventricles in a 1-1 ratio.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tachyarrhythmia originating either from the atria or the atrioventricular node.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a tachycardia which does not originate in the ventricles or His Purkinje system. There is an abnormally high heart rate and QRS complexes are typically narrow, but aberration or preexcitation may be present. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An adverse event characterized by premature atrial contractions of the heart caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites or the atrioventricular node.

Concepts.definition: An adverse event characterized by premature atrial contractions of the heart caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites or the atrioventricular node.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An arrhythmia originating from centers proximal to the ventricles, namely in the atrium, AV node, or AV junction, in contrast to arrhythmias arising in the ventricles themselves.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an arrhythmia originating in the atrium, AV node or AV junction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Nodal arrhythmia is arrythmia occurring when the atrioventricular node or surrounding junctional tissue is acting as pacemaker.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an arrhythmia originating from within the atrioventricular node.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An episodic form of atrial tachycardia, with abrupt onset and termination.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of episodic atrial tachycardia with abrupt onset and termination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of an organized, regular atrial rhythm with atrial rate of 240-340 beats per minute. Multiple P waves typically appear in the inferior leads in a saw tooth-like pattern between the QRS complexes. (CDISC)

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of an organized, regular atrial rhythm with atrial rate of 240-340 beats per minute. Multiple P waves typically appear in the inferior leads in a saw tooth-like pattern between the QRS complexes. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A supraventricular arrhythmia characterized by uncoordinated atrial myocardium activation due to multiple reentry circuits with consequent deterioration of atrial mechanical function. Instead of intermittently contracting, the atria quiver continuously in a chaotic pattern, causing a totally irregular, often tachycardia ventricular rate. On the ECG it is described by the replacement of consistent P waves by rapid oscillations or fibrillatory waves that vary in size, shape, and timing, associated with an irregular, frequently rapid ventricular response when atrioventricular conduction is intact.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a supraventricular arrhythmia characterized by the replacement of consistent P waves by rapid oscillations or fibrillatory waves that vary in size, shape and timing and are accompanied by an irregular ventricular response. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An adverse event characterized by an abnormally long interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the heart's electrical cycle, corrected for heart rate.

Concepts.definition: An adverse event characterized by an abnormally long interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the heart's electrical cycle, corrected for heart rate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A congenital electrical function abnormality in the heart. It is characterized by the presence of an accessory conductive pathway between the atria and the ventricles which causes the activation of the ventricles earlier than anticipated. Characteristic electrocardiographic findings are a short PR interval and a wide QRS complex with a delta wave.

Concepts.definition: A cardiac conduction disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of ventricular pre-excitation, which is a short PR interval and a long QRS interval with a delta wave. Most individuals are asymptomatic; however they can experience periods of palpitations, shortness of breath or syncope during tachycardic episodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by a dysrhythmia without cardiac electrical activity. Typically, this is accompanied by cessation of the pumping function of the heart.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by a dysrhythmia without cardiac electrical activity. Typically, this is accompanied by cessation of the pumping function of the heart.

PermissibleValues.value: AV block: Third degree (Complete AV block)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Atrioventricular block: Third degree (Complete AV block)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Atrioventricular block: Third degree (Complete AV block)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Complete failure of atrial electrical impulse conduction through the AV node to the ventricles.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of complete failure of atrial electrical impulse conduction to the ventricles. This is manifested on the ECG by disassociation of atrial and ventricular rhythms. The atrial rate must be faster than the ventricular rate. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A delay or failure in the conduction of a cardiac impulse from the atria to the ventricles at the level of the atrioventricular node.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of delayed or blocked cardiac electrical impulse conduction from the atria to the ventricles at the level of the atrioventricular node.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An episode of sudden and transient loss of consciousness sometimes associated with seizures. It is caused by a sudden decrease of the cardiac output that results from a sudden cardiac dysrhythmia. Typically patients develop an initial pallor, followed by facial flush during recovery.

Concepts.definition: An episode of sudden and transient loss of consciousness sometimes associated with seizures. It is caused by a sudden decrease of the cardiac output that results from a sudden cardiac dysrhythmia. Typically patients develop an initial pallor, followed by facial flush during recovery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of abnormally rapid heart rate with its origin in the sinus node. Thresholds for different age, gender, and patient populations exist. (CDISC)

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of abnormally rapid heart rate with its origin in the sinus node. Thresholds for different age, gender, and patient populations exist. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of abnormally slow heart rate with its origin in the sinus node. Thresholds for different age, gender, and patient populations exist. (CDISC)

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of abnormally slow heart rate with its origin in the sinus node. Thresholds for different age, gender, and patient populations exist. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A constellation of signs and symptoms which may include syncope, fatigue, dizziness, and alternating periods of bradycardia and atrial tachycardia, which is caused by sinoatrial node dysfunction.

Concepts.definition: A constellation of signs and symptoms which may include syncope, fatigue, dizziness, and alternating periods of bradycardia and atrial tachycardia, which is caused by sinoatrial node dysfunction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure which records the electrical current in the heart in the form of a continuous strip graph. The electrocardiography results may determine whether the heart is performing normally or suffering from abnormalities, may indicate coronary artery blockages, can be used for detecting calcium, magnesium and other electrolyte disturbances, allow the detection of conduction abnormalities, indicate the physical shape of a patient during stress test and provide information on the physical condition of the heart.: A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that displays the electrical activity of the heart.
A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding that the cardiac rhythm is initiated by an electrical impulse from a mechanical cardiac pacemaker.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding in which the cardiac rhythm is controlled by an electrical impulse from an artificial cardiac pacemaker. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding defined by prolongation of the QRS complex. It is caused by damage of one of the bundle branches, resulting in the delay or obstruction of the conduction of electrical impulses.

Concepts.longName: Bundle Branch Block by ECG Finding
Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of a prolongation of the QRS complex. It is caused by damage to one of the bundle branches, resulting in impaired transmission of cardiac electrical impulses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrocardiographic finding of a cardiac rhythm that originates in the sinoatrial node and is considered normal for the population.

Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an atrial rhythm which originates from the sinoatrial node that is considered normal for the population. There are no extra beats or conduction abnormalities. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status.: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::10: The number of occurrences of something within a minute of time.: An electrocardiographic finding of a ventricular impulse originating before depolarization has completed.

Concepts.definition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The number of occurrences of something within a minute of time.

Concepts.longName: Ventricular Premature Complex by ECG Finding
Concepts.definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an ectopic impulse originating in the ventricles. The QRS morphology of these complexes is different from those of supraventricular origin. The QRS duration is often longer and the RR interval preceding the complexes is usually shorter than that of supraventricular beats. (CDISC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.: Blood deficiency in an organ or tissue caused by a constriction or obstruction of its blood vessels.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

Concepts.definition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.
Lack of blood supply to an area of the body, resulting in impairment of tissue oxygenation.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not new, of an earlier time.: Blood deficiency in an organ or tissue caused by a constriction or obstruction of its blood vessels.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

Concepts.definition: Not new, of an earlier time.
Lack of blood supply to an area of the body, resulting in impairment of tissue oxygenation.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

Concepts.definition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Deviating from the norm.

Concepts.definition: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

PermissibleValues.value: AV block: Second degree Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Atrioventricular block: Second degree Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Atrioventricular block: Second degree Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of intermittent failure of atrial electrical impulse conduction to the ventricles, characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval prior to the block of an atrial impulse. (CDISC)

Concepts.longName: AV Block Second Degree Mobitz Type I
Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of intermittent failure of atrial electrical impulse conduction to the ventricles, characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval prior to the block of an atrial impulse. (CDISC)

PermissibleValues.value: AV block: Second degree Mobitz Type II
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Atrioventricular block: Second degree Mobitz Type II

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Atrioventricular block: Second degree Mobitz Type II
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of intermittent failure of atrial electrical impulse conduction to the ventricles, characterized by a relatively constant PR interval prior to the block of an atrial impulse. (CDISC)

Concepts.longName: AV Block Second Degree Mobitz Type II
Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of intermittent failure of atrial electrical impulse conduction to the ventricles, characterized by a relatively constant PR interval prior to the block of an atrial impulse. (CDISC)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Results of graphic tracing and measurements of the variations in electrical potential caused by the excitation of the heart muscle and detected at the body surface in relation to the diagnosis of coronary events compared with the absolute level of the measurement. The concept encompasses entirely normal, nonspecifically abnormal, and clearly abnormal findings.:Arrhythmia; an abnormal rate of muscle contractions in the heart.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Graphic representation and categorization of the electrical vectors produced by the depolarization and repolarization of myocardial tissue.
Any variation from the normal rate or rhythm (which may include the origin of the impulse and/or its subsequent propagation) in the heart.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: VD v2.0 corrects the misspelling of two permissible values containing 'Mobitz (not Motitz) and two value meanings.
ValueDomain.administrativeNotes: 2023.8.24 Updated PV defs for 'No Value Exists'. ak

DataElement.changeDescription: v2.0 uses new version of the VD in order to correct misspellings in the permissible values (Mobitz) and value meanings.
